resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

westonpace commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928182752


   This is `ALL null -> null` correct?  I.e. this adds support for `null + null => null` but it does not add support for `null + 7 => null`?  Do we support casting to null in dispatch best?


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: github-unsubscribe@arrow.apache.org

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

lidavidm commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928183552


   Yes, this is the NA/Null type. For mixed nulls, that sort of thing should generally be supported already, at least for binary functions.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: github-unsubscribe@arrow.apache.org

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

westonpace commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928184939


   Right.  But for addition you could have...
   
   ```
   arr1 = pa.array([None, None], pa.null
   arr2 = pa.array([1, 2])
   pc.add(arr1, arr2)
   ```
   
   I don't think this covers that, correct?


--

   Right.  But for addition you could have...
   
   ```
   arr1 = pa.array([None, None], pa.null)
   arr2 = pa.array([1, 2])
   pc.add(arr1, arr2)
   ```
   
   I don't think this covers that, correct?

lidavidm commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928186283


   This doesn't cover that because it's already supported, even in 5.0:
   
   ```
   >>> import pyarrow as pa
   >>> import pyarrow.compute as pc
   >>> arr1 = pa.array([None, None], pa.null())
   >>> arr2 = pa.array([1, 2])
   >>> pc.add(arr1, arr2)
   <pyarrow.lib.Int64Array object at 0x7f1e632df100>
   [
     null,
     null
   ]
   ```


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

lidavidm commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928186956


   Though if this isn't properly supported in your testing then we should probably take care of that.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

westonpace commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928192777


   My type testing typically doesn't test mixed types (e.g. `add(int64, int32)`) any longer (there are some exceptions) since I assume that is handled mostly by casting.  If this is getting handled because dispatch best is casting null up to int64 (and is willing to cast null up to any data type) then I don't think I need to test it.  On the other hand, if this is handled by registering some explicit kernels to handle "some null" then I probably should include it.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: github-unsubscribe@arrow.apache.org

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

lidavidm commented on pull request #11255:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11255#issuecomment-928193820


   Ah, ok. Those cases are indeed handled by casting in DispatchBest, not by registering individual kernels. This PR registers a separate kernel for the all-null-type case mostly because it's easiest and there isn't really an obvious type to cast to otherwise.


--

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
The compute functions today have mixed support for null types.

Unary arithmetic functions (e.g. abs) don't support null arrays

Binary arithmetic functions (e.g. add) support one null array (e.g. int32 + null) but not both null arrays (i.e. null + null) but they do support both values being null (e.g. [null] + [null] = [null] if dtype=int32 but not supported if dtype=null)

sort_indices should support null arrays.

Some functions do forward null arrays:
 - unique

Some functions output a non-null type given null inputs

- is_null (=> boolean)
- is_valid (=> boolean)
- value_counts (=> struct)
- dictionary_encode (=> dictionary<null>)
- count (=> int64)


Some functions throw an error other than "not implemented"

 - list_parent_indices
fields.summary: [C++] Uniform null handling in compute functions
